sen.j: 小石 元俊（こいし げんしゅん、寛保3年（1743年） - 文化 (元号)5年12月25日 (旧暦)（1809年2月9日）は、江戸時代後期の蘭学者、蘭方医。
sen.e: Genshun KOISHI (1743-February 9, 1809) was a Rangakusha (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language) and Ranpoi (a person who studied Western medicine by means of the Dutch language) in the late Edo period.

Genshun KOISHI (1743-February 9, 1809) was a Rangakusha (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language) and Ranpoi (a person who studied Western medicine by means of the Dutch language) in the late Edo period.

Genshun KOISHI (1743-February 9, 1809) was a Rangakusha (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language) and Ranpoi (a person who studied Western medicine by means of the Dutch language) in the late Edo period.

sen.j: 元俊は通称で、名は国瑞。
sen.e: Genshun' was his by-name, and his real name was 'Kokuzui.'
Genshun' was his by-name, and his real name was 'Kokuzui.'
Genshun' was his by-name, and his real name was 'Kokuzui.'

sen.j: 幼名は太吉。
sen.e: His childhood name was 'Taikichi.'
His childhood name was 'Taikichi.'
His childhood name was 'Taikichi.'

sen.j: 字は有素、号に大愚、碧霞山人。
sen.e: His azana (courtesy name in adulthood) was 'Yuso,' and his go (pseudonym) were 'Daigu' and 'Hekikasan.'
sen.cmt: 有素、大愚、碧霞山人 読み方不明
sen.e: His azana (courtesy name in adulthood) was 'Yuso,' and his go (pseudonym) were 'Daigu' and 'Hekikasan.'
His azana (courtesy name in adulthood) was 'Yuso,' and his go (pseudonym) were 'Daigu' and 'Hekikasan.'

sen.j: 子は小石元瑞。
sen.e: Genzui KOISHI was his children.
Genzui KOISHI was his children.
Genzui KOISHI was his children.

sen.j: 門弟に斉藤方策、南部伯民、橋本宗吉らがいる。
sen.e: Hosaku SAITO, Hakumin NANBU, and Sokichi HASHIMOTO numbered among his pupils.
sen.cmt: 斉藤方策, 南部伯民 読み方不明
sen.e: Hosaku SAITO, Hakumin NANBU, and Sokichi HASHIMOTO numbered among his pupils.
Hosaku SAITO, Hakumin NANBU, and Sokichi HASHIMOTO numbered among his pupils.

sen.j: 山脇東洋の孫弟子にあたり、関西における蘭医学の主唱者。
sen.e: His master's teacher was Toyo YAMAWAKI, and Genshun was a leading proponent of Ranigaku (Western medicine) in Kansai (western Japan).
His master's teacher was Toyo YAMAWAKI, and Genshun was a leading proponent of Ranigaku (Western medicine) in Kansai (western Japan).
His master's teacher was Toyo YAMAWAKI, and Genshun was a leading proponent of Ranigaku (Western medicine) in Kansai (western Japan).

sen.j: 杉田玄白『蘭学事始』にも名が見られ、玄白や大槻玄沢ら江戸の蘭学者とも交友た。
sen.e: His name can be found in "Rangaku Kotohajime" (The Beginning of Dutch Studies) authored by Genpaku SUGITA because he was acquainted with Rangakusha in Edo, such as Genpaku and Gentaku OTSUKI.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: His name can be found in "Rangaku Kotohajime" (The Beginning of Dutch Studies) authored by Genpaku SUGITA because he was acquainted with Rangakusha in Edo, such as Genpaku and Gentaku OTSUKI.
His name can be found in "Rangaku Kotohajime" (The Beginning of Dutch Studies) authored by Genpaku SUGITA because he was acquainted with Rangakusha in Edo, such as Genpaku and Gentaku OTSUKI.

sen.j: 東西の蘭学を結びつける人物とも位置づけられる。
sen.e: Genshun is also considered a person who ensured liaison between eastern and western Rangakusha.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Genshun is also considered a person who ensured liaison between eastern and western Rangakusha.
Genshun is also considered a person who ensured liaison between eastern and western Rangakusha.

sen.j: 山城国桂村（現在の京都市西京区桂）に生まれる。
sen.e: He was born in the village of Katsura, Yamashiro Province (currently, Katsura, Nishikyo Ward, Kyoto City).
He was born in the village of Katsura, Yamashiro Province (currently, Katsura, Nishikyo Ward, Kyoto City).
He was born in the village of Katsura, Yamashiro Province (currently, Katsura, Nishikyo Ward, Kyoto City).

sen.j: 父は若狭国小浜藩家老林野氏の出自で、流浪中に小石姓に改めたという。
sen.e: His father came from the Rinno family, the chief retainer of the Obama Domain in Wakasa Province, and it is said that his father changed his name to 'Koishi' while leading an itinerant life.
His father came from the Rinno family, the chief retainer of the Obama Domain in Wakasa Province, and it is said that his father changed his name to 'Koishi' while leading an itinerant life.
His father came from the Rinno family, the chief retainer of the Obama Domain in Wakasa Province, and it is said that his father changed his name to 'Koishi' while leading an itinerant life.

sen.j: 母は後妻で柴原氏の娘。
sen.e: His mother, the second wife, was a daughter from the Shibahara family.
His mother, the second wife, was a daughter from the Shibahara family.
His mother, the second wife, was a daughter from the Shibahara family.

sen.j: 寛延3年（1750年）、父に従い大坂へ移る。
sen.e: In 1750, Genshun moved to Osaka, accompanying his father.
In 1750, Genshun moved to Osaka, accompanying his father.
In 1750, Genshun moved to Osaka, accompanying his father.

sen.j: 医学を志し、宝暦年（1751年）には山脇東洋門下で柳河藩医淡輪元潜に師事し、元俊と改める。
sen.e: Aspiring to study medicine, he became a pupil of Gensen TANNOWA, the disciple of Toyo YAMAWAKI and a doctor for the Yanagawa Domain, and he changed his name to 'Genshun.'
Aspiring to study medicine, he became a pupil of Gensen TANNOWA, the disciple of Toyo YAMAWAKI and a doctor for the Yanagawa Domain, and he changed his name to 'Genshun.'
Aspiring to study medicine, he became a pupil of Gensen TANNOWA, the disciple of Toyo YAMAWAKI and a doctor for the Yanagawa Domain, and he changed his name to 'Genshun.'

sen.j: 元潜の紹介で同じく東洋門下の永富独嘯庵にも学び、オランダ医学に接する。
sen.e: On referral from Gensen, he also studied under Dokshoan NAGATOMI, who was also the disciple of Toyo, and learned the Western medicine.
On referral from Gensen, he also studied under Dokshoan NAGATOMI, who was also the disciple of Toyo, and learned the Western medicine.
On referral from Gensen, he also studied under Dokshoan NAGATOMI, who was also the disciple of Toyo, and learned the Western medicine.

sen.j: 永富塾では亀井南冥、小田享叔とともに三傑と称された。
sen.e: In Nagatomi's training school, he was called 'the three greatest talents,' together with Nanmei KAMEI and Koshuku ODA.
In Nagatomi's training school, he was called 'the three greatest talents,' together with Nanmei KAMEI and Koshuku ODA.
In Nagatomi's training school, he was called 'the three greatest talents,' together with Nanmei KAMEI and Koshuku ODA.

sen.j: また河内の僧慈雲に参禅。
sen.e: He also practiced Zen under Jiun, a bonze in Kawachi.
He also practiced Zen under Jiun, a bonze in Kawachi.
He also practiced Zen under Jiun, a bonze in Kawachi.

sen.j: 明和元年（1764年）には父が死去。
sen.e: In 1764, his father passed away.
In 1764, his father passed away.
In 1764, his father passed away.

sen.j: この頃西国を遊歴する。
sen.e: In this period, he traveled from place to place in western provinces.
In this period, he traveled from place to place in western provinces.
In this period, he traveled from place to place in western provinces.

sen.j: 明和6年に大坂で衛生館を開業。
sen.e: In1769, he opened Eiseikan (Hall of Hygiene) in Osaka.
In1769, he opened Eiseikan (Hall of Hygiene) in Osaka.
In1769, he opened Eiseikan (Hall of Hygiene) in Osaka.

sen.j: 安永6年（1777年）亀井冥南の影響で皆川淇園の家塾に入門し、『元衍』の著述に専念、陰陽五行説に基づく旧態医学を批判。
sen.e: Influenced by Nanmei KAMEI, he enrolled in a government-backed school operated by Kien MINAGAWA and immersed himself in writing the book "Genen" (Fundamental Flow), whereby he criticized the old-fashioned medicine based on Onmyo-gogyo-setsu (Chinese traditional pseudo-science built on five elements).

Influenced by Nanmei KAMEI, he enrolled in a government-backed school operated by Kien MINAGAWA and immersed himself in writing the book "Genen" (Fundamental Flow), whereby he criticized the old-fashioned medicine based on Onmyo-gogyo-setsu (Chinese traditional pseudo-science built on five elements).

Influenced by Nanmei KAMEI, he enrolled in a government-backed school operated by Kien MINAGAWA and immersed himself in writing the book "Genen" (Fundamental Flow), whereby he criticized the old-fashioned medicine based on Onmyo-gogyo-setsu (Chinese traditional pseudo-science built on five elements).

sen.j: 皆川塾では柴野栗山らと交友し頼春水から歴史を学ぶ。
sen.e: In Minagawa's school, he enjoyed friendship with Ritsuzan SHIBANO and others and learned history from Shunsui RAI.
In Minagawa's school, he enjoyed friendship with Ritsuzan SHIBANO and others and learned history from Shunsui RAI.
In Minagawa's school, he enjoyed friendship with Ritsuzan SHIBANO and others and learned history from Shunsui RAI.

sen.j: 浦上玉堂や木村蒹葭堂ら著名な文人とも親しく交わった。
sen.e: He was also acquainted with famous intellectuals such as Gyokudo URAGAMI and Kenkado KIMURA.
He was also acquainted with famous intellectuals such as Gyokudo URAGAMI and Kenkado KIMURA.
He was also acquainted with famous intellectuals such as Gyokudo URAGAMI and Kenkado KIMURA.

sen.j: 天明3年（1783年）には伏見で人体解剖を行う。
sen.e: In 1783, he dissected a human body for examination in Fushimi.
In 1783, he dissected a human body for examination in Fushimi.
In 1783, he dissected a human body for examination in Fushimi.

sen.j: この年には妻帯。
sen.e: He had a spouse in this year.
He had a spouse in this year.
He had a spouse in this year.

sen.j: 息子小石元瑞を幼少の頃より大坂の友人篠崎三島に入門させている。
sen.e: He had his son, Genzui KOISHI, become a pupil of Santo SHINOZAKI, his friend in Osaka, when Genzui was still a young child.
He had his son, Genzui KOISHI, become a pupil of Santo SHINOZAKI, his friend in Osaka, when Genzui was still a young child.
He had his son, Genzui KOISHI, become a pupil of Santo SHINOZAKI, his friend in Osaka, when Genzui was still a young child.

sen.j: 安永3年に江戸で出版された『解体新書』に触発され、同年に杉田玄白、大槻玄沢に相次いで合うと、江戸に出て東遊し、大槻邸に滞在した。
sen.e: Energized by "Kaitai Shinsho" (the historic Japanese translation of a Dutch anatomical text) published in Edo in 1774, he visited Genpaku SUGITA and Gentaku OTSUKI in a row and stayed in Edo to collect information, sojourning at Otsuki's residence.

Energized by "Kaitai Shinsho" (the historic Japanese translation of a Dutch anatomical text) published in Edo in 1774, he visited Genpaku SUGITA and Gentaku OTSUKI in a row and stayed in Edo to collect information, sojourning at Otsuki's residence.

Energized by "Kaitai Shinsho" (the historic Japanese translation of a Dutch anatomical text) published in Edo in 1774, he visited Genpaku SUGITA and Gentaku OTSUKI in a row and stayed in Edo to collect information, sojourning at Otsuki's residence.

sen.j: 天明8年（1788年）の天明の京都大火で『元衍』を焼失。
sen.e: In 1788, his book "Genen" was burned due to the Great Kyoto Fire of the Tenmei period.
In 1788, his book "Genen" was burned due to the Great Kyoto Fire of the Tenmei period.
In 1788, his book "Genen" was burned due to the Great Kyoto Fire of the Tenmei period.

sen.j: 寛政8年（1796年）にも人体解剖を行い、『施薬院解男体臓図』として著す。
sen.e: He dissected a human body also in 1796 and reported results in his book "Seyaku-in Kainantai Zozu" (Pharmacy Institution Edition of the Anatomy of Male's Body).
sen.cmt: 施薬院解男体臓図」読み方不明
sen.e: He dissected a human body also in 1796 and reported results in his book "Seyaku-in Kainantai Zozu" (Pharmacy Institution Edition of the Anatomy of Male's Body).
He dissected a human body also in 1796 and reported results in his book "Seyaku-in Kainantai Zozu" (Pharmacy Institution Edition of the Anatomy of Male's Body).

sen.j: 享和元年（1801年）、京都で医学塾・究理堂を開き、上方での蘭学拡大に貢献した。
sen.e: In 1801, he opened his own medicine school, Kyuri-do, in Kyoto and contributed to the spread of Ranguku in Kansai.
In 1801, he opened his own medicine school, Kyuri-do, in Kyoto and contributed to the spread of Ranguku in Kansai.
In 1801, he opened his own medicine school, Kyuri-do, in Kyoto and contributed to the spread of Ranguku in Kansai.

sen.j: 間重富と共同出資で、傘職人の橋本宗吉を江戸の芝蘭堂へ学ばせた。
sen.e: Through join-investment with Shigetomi HAZAMA, he stationed Sokichi HASHIMOTO, an umbrella craftsman, to Shiran-do in Edo (for the master of Rangaku).
Through join-investment with Shigetomi HAZAMA, he stationed Sokichi HASHIMOTO, an umbrella craftsman, to Shiran-do in Edo (for the master of Rangaku).
Through join-investment with Shigetomi HAZAMA, he stationed Sokichi HASHIMOTO, an umbrella craftsman, to Shiran-do in Edo (for the master of Rangaku).

sen.j: 66歳で死去。
sen.e: Genshun died at the age of 66.
Genshun died at the age of 66.
Genshun died at the age of 66.

sen.j: 著作に『元衍』、『学医要論』、『有因心論』。
sen.e: His works are "Genen," "Guide to Medical Study," and "Yuin Shin-ron" (Theory of Psychological Causes).
sen.cmt: 『学医要論』、『有因心論』定訳不明
sen.e: His works are "Genen," "Guide to Medical Study," and "Yuin Shin-ron" (Theory of Psychological Causes).
His works are "Genen," "Guide to Medical Study," and "Yuin Shin-ron" (Theory of Psychological Causes).

sen.j: 墓所は京都市北区の大徳寺孤蓬庵。
sen.e: His graveyard is located at Koho-an, a subsidiary temple within Daitoku-ji Temple, in Kita Ward, Kyoto City.
His graveyard is located at Koho-an, a subsidiary temple within Daitoku-ji Temple, in Kita Ward, Kyoto City.
His graveyard is located at Koho-an, a subsidiary temple within Daitoku-ji Temple, in Kita Ward, Kyoto City.
